column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=David Shankbone :
#Text=How is that ?
#Text=It 's turned into a much bigger piece of community service than I thought it would be .
#Text=It started without major expectations .
#Text=At that time I had been drafted into it , there were still places to get literary books covered , it felt like .
#Text=There was a VLS ; there was a New York Press .
#Text=VLS does n't exist anymore . . . it 's a big deal .
#Text=All the alternative media is either becoming a conglomerate , like the Village Voice , or it 's dying , like the New York Press .
#Text=The Village Voice may be dying , too .
#Text=It 's been bought and resold so many times , I do n't really understand what it is anymore .
#Text=I interviewed Michael Musto , and that was one area that I wanted to touch on , but we got involved in so many other things .
#Text=I do n't even know how much I could really get out of somebody who 's working there , but --
#Text=I would love to know what he thinks about it .
#Text=But the Rail is doing well -- I like covering all those books .
#Text=How does the Rail make its money in order to operate ?
#Text=Well , the Rail is really doing well .
#Text=They are getting grants and I 'm a little bit astonished at how well they do .
#Text=I think the Rail is in a good position to pull it together and bring itself to the next level .
#Text=I 'm not over there at the office every day , but that 's my impression of it .

#Text=What about this theory that the drop in advertising for the print media , even though it 's going to go through a period of growing pains , in the end might actually be better for the literary press like the Brooklyn Rail , because people who have keys to funding will see more of a need to do grants , which will allow them to be more experimental as opposed to worrying about , " Are we going to offend our advertisers ? "
#Text=It may work that way .
#Text=There is a gigantic fragmenting because , because the new venues for literary books are not just in print media .
#Text=They 're on the Internet ; there are millions of these micropresses now .
#Text=So many I ca n't keep track of them .
#Text=And a lot of them are publishing really good books .
#Text=Many are not concerned with getting reviews .
#Text=They just do n't care .
#Text=They 're willing to do a very small print run to facilitate their sales through networking sites , and a few literary blogs or literary sites -- and there are a lot of them now .
#Text=And of course , as these things condense from one thing to the next and grow into larger organisms , there 's going to be a fair share of power there filtered down to the small presses .
